The construction of porous materials such as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is one of the most promising routes to achieve a suitable storage mechanism for molecular H
MOFs are crystalline compounds that are synthesized from metal ions and organic ligands.
They are three-dimensional materials containing pores and channels that can be used to sorb and store H
. MOFs are highly tunable as several different structures can be made by changing the metal ion or ligand.
sorption in MOFs is based on physisorption, where the interaction energy between the H
molecule and the framework is rather weak, especially compared to that for a chemical bond. The previously described features allow MOFs to have advantages over traditional materials for H
storage, such as zeolites, activated carbons, and metal hydrides. A H

Inelastic neutron scattering (INS) is a useful spectroscopic technique that can be used to gain atomistically detailed insights into the energetics for H
sorbed at various sorption sites in MOFs. The INS spectra for H
in MOFs consist of many peaks from transitions of the hindered H
rotor, where typically each transition corresponds to H
sorbed at a particular site in the MOF. Rotational tunneling transitions that appear at low energies correspond to a high barrier to rotation for the sorbed H
, which is indicative of a strong interaction with the framework.
INS studies have been performed on several MOFs to obtain information on the rotational barriers for H
at different sorption sites in these materials. As an example, INS studies on Ni-DOBDC revealed a transition at 6.6 meV in the spectra for the MOF, which is the lowest energy peak in the spectra.
This 6.6 meV peak, representing the sorption of H
ions in the MOF, corresponds to a rotational barrier of 37.7 meV acccording to an empirical phenomenological model that is based on a simple double-minimum potential.

sorption in a fluorinated MOF containing small pore sizes is investigated through theoretical and INS studies. The MOF is a recently synthesized material that consists of Zn
ions that are coordinated to 1,2,4-triazole (trz) and tetrafluoroterephthalate (tftph) ligands (Figure
The empirical formula for the structure of the MOF is [Zn
]. Preparation of the MOF involves removing an extrinsic water molecule via activation. However, upon desolvation of the framwork, one H
O molecule remains coordinated to one type of Zn

ion. This MOF, denoted [Zn(trz)(tftph)] throughout this manuscript, is notable for the small pore sizes that it contains as well as for the  presence of accessible fluorine atoms from the tftph ligands that project into the pores with a partial negative charge conducive to sorbate binding. The MOF contains three different types of Zn
ions and three chemically distinct trz linkers (see
). Closer inspection of the crystal structure of the MOF suggests that the free carboxylate oxygen atoms from the tftph ligands (i.e., those that are not coordinated to a Zn
ion) are also accessible to provide binding opportunities.
The experimental INS spectra for H
at different loadings in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] are presented. Details of performing the INS measurements can be found in the
. INS studies were performed for H
in this MOF to assess the importance of small pore sizes or fluorine functionality on the rotational dynamics of H

in porous materials. The study also serves to highlight the synergy between such spectroscopic measurements and careful theoretical modeling. The resultant INS spectra reveal 2–3 rotational tunneling transitions, with one of them occurring at a noticeably low energy (5.4 meV), which indicates a high barrier to rotation for a specific sorption site. The transition energy for this peak is lower than the lowest energy peak for most neutral MOFs that contain open-metal sites
and is comparable to those MOFs that are charged and possess counterions.
Grand canonical Monte Carlo (GCMC) simulations of H
sorption were performed in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] in this work in order to identify the H
sorption sites. Details of the GCMC simulations are provided in the
. Further, details of preparing and parametrizing the MOF for simulations can also be found in the
. Accurate molecular level predictions of the H
sorption sites in MOFs are predicated on the ability to obtain good agreement with experimental measurements. It will be shown that the simulated H
values produced in this work in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] are consistent with those quantities that were obtained experimentally. Experimental studies of H
sorption in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] have shown that the MOF displays an initial H
This value is impressive for a material that excludes open-metal sites. The high
in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] must be attributed to H

interacting with several polar functionalities in the small space of the framework. It will be shown that the interactions are dominated by repulsion/dispersion energetics that are synergistically enhanced because of the MOF topology. Moreover, this
value is higher than some MOFs that contain open-metal sites, with the most notable example being HKUST-1 (or Cu-BTC).
It will be shown that a cooperative interaction from several different moieties in a confined region in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] is responsible for the high H
value in the material as well as for the presence of the lowest energy peak in the INS spectra for the MOF. We also calculate the rotational potential energy surface for a H

molecule sorbed at the primary site in [Zn(trz)(tftph)]. It will be revealed later that the theoretical value is in good agreement with a value that was determined using an empirical phenomenological model.
Additionally, it will be shown that the rotational barrier for H
at the most favorable sorption site in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] is among the highest of reported MOF materials on the basis of INS measurements and calculations.
were performed in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] using three different potentials of increasing complexity: single-site van der Waals potential developed by V. Buch (Buch),
five-site electrostatic (nonpolarizable) potential by Belof et al. (BSS),
and five-site polarizable potential by Belof et al. (BSSP).
For simulations using the BSSP model, polarization was included explicitly in the simulations via a Thole–Applequist type model.
All simulations were performed in the rigid 2 × 2 × 2 system cell of the MOF as shown in Figure

). Experimental studies on [Zn(trz)(tftph)] have shown that these metal-coordinated H
O molecules are part of the MOF and that the removal of these molecules causes the framework to collapse.

a. All experimental data were estimated from the original experimental reference for this MOF (ref

sorption isotherm for the Buch model in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] is coincident with experiment at 77 K for the entire pressure range considered. This is typically a bad indicator because the model is physically inadequate if the results differ for the more generally applicable and accurate BSS and BSSP models (see below). This does, however, suggest that the H

sorption observables in this MOF can be captured by considering only van der Waals interactions, at least if the agreement persists at temperatures other than 77 K. Simulations using the BSS and BSSP models generated isotherms that are only slightly higher than the experimental isotherm and the isotherm produced by the Buch model at 77 K, especially at pressures from 0.05 atm (38 mmHg) and above. The slight oversorption for the BSS and BSSP models compared to experiment for nearly all pressures considered at 77 K could be because a perfect crystal of the MOF was used for the simulations. Actual synthesized crystals could have minor deformations, and such alterations are likely to result in partially blocked pores for MOFs that have very narrow pore sizes. Still, these isotherms for the BSS and BSSP models are considered to be representative of the experiment, especially on the basis of the broad success of these hydrogen potentials in MOFs.

Consistent with the relative succes of the Buch model, the BSS and BSSP models show that electrostatic interactions have a negligible effect on H
sorption in this MOF. Indeed, H
sorption in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] is dominated by van der Waals (repulsion/dispersion) interactions because of the small pores that are present in the framework. Smaller pores would allow the H
molecules to interact with multiple portions of the framework simultaneously,

thus causing van der Waals interactions to dominate. This was confirmed by examining the energy decomposition for each model, as it was revealed that Lennard-Jones interactions contribute to at least 90% of the total energy for the BSS and BSSP models for all state points considered. In addition, the fact that the BSS and BSSP models produced essentially the same isotherm in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] indicates that polarization interactions are insignificant for H
sorption in this MOF. Although polarization has been shown to be important for simulations of H
sorption in MOFs that contain open-metal sites,

these interactions are negligible in MOFs that contain narrow pore sizes and exclude such metal centers. Apparently, the negatively charged constituents like the fluorine atoms in this MOF do not participate significantly in such interactions as well.
It can be observed in Figure

a that the Buch model undersorbs the experimental isotherm in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] at 87 K for all pressures considered. As for the BSS and BSSP models, these potentials produced isotherms that are in good agreement with experiment at 87 K for pressures up to 0.60 atm (456 mmHg). At higher pressures at 87 K, however, both models undersorb experiment, with the largest difference between experiment and simulation being observed at nearly 1.2 atm (912 mmHg). The isotherms generated by all three models do not capture the shape of the experimental isotherm at 87 K particularly well. The simulated isotherms at 87 K are essentially a scaled version of those generated at 77 K as typically seen in analogous experiments over this relatively cold and narrow temperature range. Such shape differences usually indicate a structural differentiation in either sorbate binding or MOF structure that are not especially likely in this case. The difference in the shape of the 87 K sorption isotherm between experiment and simulation reflects the fact that the H

uptake is trending toward saturation in the MOF more quickly under experimental conditions at this temperature. Despite this difference, we believe that the simulated results (considering all models) are in reasonable agreement with experiment at 87 K for all pressures considered.

in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] reveal three peaks occurring at approximately 5.4, 6.2, and 7.8 meV. A lower energy rotational tunneling peak in the spectra represents a sorption site that causes a high barrier to rotation on the sorbed H
molecule to exhibit a stronger interaction with the framework. Because the site depicted in Figure
a is the most favorable sorption site within the material, it makes sense that this site corresponds to the 5.4 meV peak in the INS spectra.
At the lowest loading measured (1.8 H

/formula unit), the peak at 6.2 meV is the most prominent of any of the three peaks in the spectra, while the peak at 5.4 meV exists as a low energy shoulder of the 6.2 meV peak. This indicates that, at low loadings, the most energetically favorable site in the MOF is not fully populated first. At a loading of 2.7 H

/formula unit, the intensity of the 5.4 meV peak increases significantly, while the 6.2 meV peak virtually disappears. In addition, the peak occurring at 7.8 meV becomes more noticeable at this loading. This 7.8 meV peak corresponds to the weakest sorption site in the MOF. In this case, it is the secondary sorption site in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] as shown in Figure
Although we have identified only two noticeable sorption sites for H

in [Zn(trz)(tftph)], the INS spectra suggest that there are perhaps three sorption sites in the MOF. We have already assigned the 5.4 and 7.8 meV peaks as the primary and secondary sites in the MOF, respectively. Further calculations and inspection of the modeled structure for H
in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] reveal that the sorption site that is associated with the 6.2 meV peak does not correspond to a new sorption site outside of those shown in Figure
but rather to a slightly shifted version of a H

molecule that is sorbed at the primary site in the MOF. Indeed, it can be deduced from the spectra that the 6.2 meV peak represents a shifted version of the 5.4 meV peak, that is, the peak at 6.2 meV shifts to lower energies (to 5.4 meV) at higher loadings. The reason for this is because when more H
molecules enter the MOF, this forces some of the sorbed H
molecules to move closer to the primary site, hence explaining the lower transition energy at higher loadings.
At the highest loading measured (4.3 H
/formula unit), the intensity of the 6.2 meV peak increases relative to that observed at 1.8 H
/formula unit for this peak. The high intensity of the 6.2 meV peak at this loading indicates that a large number of H
molecules are crowding around those molecules that are sorbed at the primary site in the MOF. Further, the intensity of the 5.4 meV peak remains similar to that observed at 2.7 H
/formula unit for this peak, while the 7.8 meV peak exists as a high energy shoulder of the 6.2 meV peak.

The transition for the lowest energy peak in the INS spectra for [Zn(trz)(tftph)] (5.4 meV) is among the lowest of reported MOF materials on the basis of previous INS studies on several MOFs that exhibit strong interactions with the sorbed H
). The value of this rotational tunneling transition is lower than the lowest energy peak for most neutral MOFs that contain open-metal Cu
and members of the M-DOBDC series.
This implies that the primary site in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] causes a higher barrier to rotation on the sorbed H

than the open-metal sites in the aforementioned MOFs. This 5.4 meV peak observed in the INS spectra for [Zn(trz)(tftph)] corresponds to a rotational barrier of 45.8 meV according to an empirical phenomenological model that is based on a simple double-minimum potential.
This barrier height is among the highest of reported MOFs that rely on physisorption interactions with the H
molecules, as it is higher than those for neutral MOFs that contain open-metal sites and comparable to those for charged MOFs that contain counterions (Table
The inference that a high rotational barrier is enforced at the primary sorption site in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] was supported by calculating the potential energy surface for a H
molecule rotating about its minimum energy coordinate at this site. This was accomplished by calculating the total potential energy of the MOF–H
molecule was rotated at various angles of θ (0–180°) and ϕ (0–360°) while keeping the center-of-mass of the molecule fixed as executed in previous work.
Single-point energies were obtained on a θ–ϕ grid (4096 points based on 64 × 64 Gaussian quadrature integration),
and the rotational barrier was estimated by taking the difference between the maximum and the minimum values on the grid. All calculations were performed on a BSSP H
molecule that was positioned at the primary site in the MOF as shown in Figure
a. The resulting rotational potential energy surface is shown in Figure

The rotational barrier was calculated to be 50.0 meV, which is in good agreement with the value that was obtained using the phenomenological model as described above. The synergistic interaction between a metal-coordinated H
O molecule, an exposed fluorine atom of a tftph linker, and a carboxylate oxygen atom of another tftph linker is responsible for causing a high barrier to rotation on the sorbed H

molecule at this site. This interaction from the different moieties at the primary site in the MOF is made possible by the small pore sizes within the material. Calculations using the BSS model at this site revealed a similar potential energy surface and rotational barrier.

Thus, to the best of our knowledge, the barrier to rotation at the primary sorption site in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] is currently the highest for a neutral MOF on the basis of INS and theoretical studies, as it narrowly beats out that for the most favorable sorption site in
, another MOF that contains narrow pore sizes and exposed fluorine atoms. Both [Zn(trz)(tftph)] and

are MOFs that exclude open-metal sites. Hence, a key finding observed in this study is that reducing the pore sizes in MOFs, coupled with appropriate chemistry from including polar functionalities, is a promising method for increasing the rotational barriers on the sorbed H

molecules in porous materials. It is expected that the inclusion of open-metal sites or counterions in such systems would increase the rotational barriers even further. The rotational barrier at the preferential sorption site in the anionic rare-earth
is currently the highest out of all MOFs reported thus far as demonstrated previously by our group through INS studies and computational modeling.
This was due to a synergistic interaction between an open-metal site, a counterion, and a nitrogen-rich region in the MOF.

values in this MOF were in good agreement with the matching experimental data. INS studies were also performed for H

in this MOF, and the resulting spectra revealed at least two peaks that occur at low energies, which corresponds to high barriers to rotation for the respective sites. The transition energy for the lowest energy peak in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] (5.4 meV) is lower than that for most neutral MOFs that contain open-metal sites and is comparable to that for charged MOFs that contain counterions.
The most favorable sorption site identified from the simulations corresponded to sorption into a confined region where the H
molecule can interact with a coordinated H
O molecule, the fluorine atom of a tftph ligand, and the carboxylate oxygen atom of another tftph ligand simultaneously. The rotational barrier for H

sorbed at this site was calculated to be 50.0 meV using a theoretical potential energy surface. The theoretical value is in good agreement to the value that was determined using an empirical phenomenological model, which is 45.8 meV. The rotational barrier for the primary sorption site in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] is notably higher than those for MOFs that contain open-metal sites. Sorption was also observed between the fluorine atoms of two neighboring tftph ligands in [Zn(trz)(tftph)]. This site has weaker energetics compared to those for the primary site, as indicated by the higher transition energy for this site in the INS spectra (7.8 meV).
It was shown that the combination of a water molecule, a fluorine atom, and a carboxylate oxygen atom in a highly compact environment gives rise to a high rotational barrier on the sorbed H

molecule. Thus, it appears that synthesizing MOFs with small pore sizes, coupled with the inclusion of favorable polar functionalities, is a promising method for increasing the sorption energetics for H
in porous materials. Indeed, the synergistic interaction from the different moieties at the primary sorption site in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] results in a H
and a rotational barrer of close to 50.0 meV. We speculate that the introduction of open-metal sites and counterions in this or similar MOF systems in some fashion would afford higher
values and rotational barriers for the sorbed H
[Zn(trz)(tftph)] is one of the few MOFs that contain a high

in the absence of open-metal sites. As observed in this work, this is due to the different moieties at the primary sorption site in the MOF as a result of the small pore sizes. Current work is underway to investigate the
values and rotational barriers for H
in other MOFs with small pore sizes through molecular simulation and INS studies. It is also planned to study CO
sorption in [Zn(trz)(tftph)] by means of experiment and simulation.

A review.  Identifying and building a sustainable energy system are perhaps 2 of the most crit. issues that today's society must address.  Replacing the current energy carrier mix with a sustainable fuel is one of the key pieces in that system.  H as an energy carrier, primarily derived from H2O, can address issues of sustainability, environmental emissions, and energy security.  Issues relating to H prodn. pathways are addressed here.  Future energy systems require money and energy to build.  Given that the United States has a finite supply of both, decisions must be made about the way forward.

Different catalysts were used for the steam reforming of ethanol.  Depending on the type of catalysts, reaction conditions, and the catalyst prepn. method, ethanol conversion and hydrogen prodn. vary greatly.  Co/ZnO, ZnO, Rh/Al2O3, Rh/CeO2, and Ni/La2O3-Al2O3 performed the best, in regard to the steam reforming of ethanol. A review.  MOFs have versatile structures, high surface areas and high pore vols. - they can be regarded as good candidate materials for H storage.  There are many MOFs that have high H adsorption capacities at low temps., typically at 77 or 87 K.  The highest H storage capacity reported so far is 99.5 mg/g at 77K and 56 bar for NU-100.  However, the high H capacities of MOFs at cryogenic temps. decrease as the temp. increases to room temp.  This is because the H adsorption in MOFs is weak physisorption and the interaction energies between the H mols. and frameworks are low.  To develop MOFs as H storage materials that meet the U.S.DOE targets for an on-board hydrogen system, a serious challenge is still present in the design and synthesis of the MOF materials.  We may expect that highly stable MOFs having a large surface area and pore vol., together with many open metal sites and embedded catalysts for hydrogen spillover, would provide some pos. results for H storage at ambient temp.

The storage of gases in porous adsorbents, such as activated carbon and carbon nanotubes, is examd. here thermodynamically from a systems viewpoint, considering the entire adsorption-desorption cycle. For carbons, for which the av. enthalpy change is typically 5.8 kJ/mol, an optimum operating temp. of about 115 K is predicted. It is also demonstrated that for max. delivery of the gas the optimum adsorbent must be homogeneous, and that introduction of heterogeneity, such as by ball milling, irradn., and other means, can only provide small increases in physisorption-related delivery for hydrogen.  For methane, heterogeneity is always detrimental, at any value of av. adsorption enthalpy change.  These results are confirmed with the help of exptl. data from the literature, as well as extensive Monte Carlo simulations conducted here using slit pore models of activated carbons as well as atomistic models of carbon nanotubes. We find that both the phonon and rotational energy levels of the hydrogen mol. are closely similar, making the interpretation of the inelastic neutron scattering data difficult. A series of fcu-MOFs based on rare-earth (RE) metals and linear fluorinated/non-fluorinated, homo/heterofunctional ligands were targeted and synthesized.  This particular face-centered cubic-metal org. frameworks (fcc-MOF) platform was selected because of its unique structural characteristics combined with the ability/potential to dictate and regulate its chem. properties (e.g., tuning of the electron-rich RE metal ions and high localized charge d., a property arising from the proximal positioning of polarizing tetrazolate moieties and fluoro-groups that decorate the exposed inner surfaces of the confined conical cavities).  These features permitted a systematic gas sorption study to evaluate/elucidate the effects of distinctive parameters on CO2-MOF sorption energetics.  Our study supports the importance of the synergistic effect of exposed open metal sites and proximal highly localized charge d. toward materials with enhanced CO2 sorption energetics.
